to help you prepare for the exam.
Distinguish between hierarchical structure and network structure in representing information

Hierarchical structures organize information in a top-down manner, with each node representing a concept or category, and subcategories or instances branching off from parent nodes. Example: schema.org.

Network structures describes a directed graph, i.e. a set of nodes that are linked by directed edges (‚Äúarrows‚Äù). Both nodes and edges are labeled with identifiers to distinguish them. Example: RDF.
Think of this as a "Tree structure."
A child node usually has only
parent. It is strict and rigid.
be used in a hierarchy, but it is often used within the network structure of the Semantic Web. A classic example of hierarchy is your computer's
Think of this as a "Spider web" or a "Graph."
Any node can connect to any other node. There is no strict "top" or "bottom."
This is the data model of the Semantic Web. It uses
(Subject  Predicate  Object) to form these directed graphs.
Outline basic internet and web technologies and describe the relation between them
(User text was brief here, so I will provide the necessary expansion directly below).
The physical network of interconnected computer networks.
TCP/IP (Transmission Control Protocol/Internet Protocol), Routers, Cables, DNS (Domain Name System).
The "Cars" and "Cargo" traveling on the roads.
Assess the characteristics of decentralisation in information system architectures
‚Ä¢ Robustness: No single point of failure, improving system resilience and reliability.
‚Ä¢ Enhanced scalability: Easily accommodate growth by adding more nodes to the network.
‚Ä¢ Reduced latency: Data processing occurs closer to users, ensuring faster response times.
In a centralized system (like a bank database), if the main server crashes, the whole system stops. In a decentralized Web, if one server crashes, the rest of the web continues to function.
You do not need permission from a central authority (like Google or a Government) to add a new page or server to the Web. You just connect it. This allows the network to grow organically.
This often refers to Content Delivery Networks (CDNs) or Edge Computing, where data is stored physically closer to the user to reduce the travel time of the signal.
Explain the network effect as expressed in Metcalfe‚Äôs Law

According to Metcalfe, the cost of a network is directly proportional to the number of cards installed (users), but the value of the network is proportional to the square of the number of users. Cost = N, but Value = N2.
A single fax machine is useless (Value = 0). Two fax machines allow 1 connection. Millions of fax machines create billions of possible connections.
. Adding one user adds a fixed amount of hardware cost.
(Exponentially). The utility of the network increases much faster than the cost.
Why it matters for Semantic Web:
This explains why linking data is so powerful. The more data you link (Linked Open Data), the exponentially more valuable the global knowledge base becomes.
Identify and name resources; tell information resources apart from other resources based on a textual description
A resource is an abstract notion for things of discourse, be they abstract or concrete, physical or virtual.
An Uniform Resource Identifier (URI) is a character sequence that identifies a resource.
URI = scheme ":" hierarchical part [ "?" query ] [ "#" fragment]
‚Ä¢ scheme: specifies type of URI. For example: http, ftp, smtp...
‚Ä¢ authority: hostname and optional port number
‚Ä¢ path: reference to content on the host server, can be interpreted in a hierarchical fashion
‚Ä¢ query: contains data that does not match tree structure
‚Ä¢ fragment: addresses local part of a document
Anything that can be transmitted electronically (as a stream of bytes) via the network.
An HTML webpage, a PDF file, a JPG image.
A person (Alice), a physical book, the concept of "Freedom," the Eiffel Tower.
You cannot "download" the Eiffel Tower; you can only download a
The specific file location or directory structure on that server.
Non-hierarchical data used for parameters (e.g., search terms). Always starts with
the returned resource (e.g., scrolling down to the paragraph about the ferret's nose). The fragment is
sent to the server; it is handled by your browser.

derived directly from the lecture material to help you prepare for the exam.
Distinguish between hierarchical structure and network structure in representing information

Hierarchical structures organize information in a top-down manner, with each node representing a concept or category, and subcategories or instances branching off from parent nodes. Example: schema.org.

Network structures describes a directed graph, i.e. a set of nodes that are linked by directed edges (‚Äúarrows‚Äù). Both nodes and edges are labeled with identifiers to distinguish them. Example: RDF.
The lecture illustrates this using the
(Paul Otlet, early 20th century) as a historical example.
It used a decimal classification system (e.g.,
Information is strictly nested (folders within folders).
The lecture contrasts hierarchy with the concept of "intertwingled" data (Ted Nelson's Xanadu)  and the Semantic Web's graph structure.
In a network, nodes are not restricted to a single parent. It is a "Web of Data" where things are interconnected universally.
This structure allows for the "linking" of documents and data across different servers.
Outline basic internet and web technologies and describe the relation between them
(No text provided by user, adding explanation based on slides).
Responsible for sending packets to devices (Addressing).
Breaks data into packets and ensures delivery.
(Internet Assigned Numbers Authority) manages IP addresses and DNS (Domain Name System).
(World Wide Web Consortium), directed by Tim Berners-Lee.
The language for encoding documents and structure.
The Web is an application that runs
the Internet infrastructure. The Internet moves the data (packets), while the Web provides the interface (documents/links) for humans and machines to interact with it.
Assess the characteristics of decentralisation in information system architectures
‚Ä¢ Robustness: No single point of failure, improving system resilience and reliability.
‚Ä¢ Enhanced scalability: Easily accommodate growth by adding more nodes to the network.
‚Ä¢ Reduced latency: Data processing occurs closer to users, ensuring faster response times.
(RFC 793) as a core concept of decentralized reliability: *"Be conservative in what you do, be liberal in what you accept"*.
Systems should be strict in what they emit (send), but flexible in what they accept from others to prevent the network from crashing due to minor errors.
The lecture emphasizes that the Web allows for
Because there is no central authority required to create a link or add a server (no lengthy permission process), the network can grow indefinitely.
Explain the network effect as expressed in Metcalfe‚Äôs Law

According to Metcalfe, the cost of a network is directly proportional to the number of cards installed (users), but the value of the network is proportional to the square of the number of users. Cost = N, but Value = N2.
Linearly proportional to the number of devices/users.
Proportional to the square of users because every new user can potentially connect to every existing user.
There is a specific point where the Value curve surpasses the Cost curve. Once this point is reached, the network becomes self-sustaining and highly profitable/valuable.
This creates a "Positive feedback loop" where the increasing value attracts even more users, further increasing the value.
Identify and name resources; tell information resources apart from other resources based on a textual description
A resource is an abstract notion for things of discourse, be they abstract or concrete, physical or virtual.
An Uniform Resource Identifier (URI) is a character sequence that identifies a resource.
URI = scheme ":" hierarchical part [ "?" query ] [ "#" fragment]
‚Ä¢ scheme: specifies type of URI. For example: http, ftp, smtp...
‚Ä¢ authority: hostname and optional port number
‚Ä¢ path: reference to content on the host server, can be interpreted in a hierarchical fashion
‚Ä¢ query: contains data that does not match tree structure
‚Ä¢ fragment: addresses local part of a document
The lecture makes a crucial distinction (often referred to as the "HTTP Range 14" issue in Semantic Web history):
Things that are digital "files" and can be transmitted over the network.
Abstract concepts or real-world objects that
Chemical elements, rooms, people, abstract concepts.

. As before, I have kept your text exactly as provided, followed by an
derived from standard Semantic Web and Linked Data principles (which align with your lecture notes).
Data models are formalism for describing all objects contained in the database and their relationships to one another or schema. Data models cover:
‚Ä¢ Structures: object types and relationship betwwen objects
‚Ä¢ Operations: extraction and linking of data. Related to query languages as SPARQL
‚Ä¢ Constrains: model properties and user-defined properties like restricted value ranges
There are three types of data models:
‚Ä¢ Structured Data Models. Are relational models such a rigid table structure with rows (tuples) and columns (attributes). Also object-oriented models like objects with attributes and methods
‚Ä¢ Semi-structured Data Models. They have structural elements in some free composition including unstructured content between the tags. RDF is an example, with labelled nodes and edges
‚Ä¢ Unstructured Data Models. Binary large models with internal structure like JPEG.

This is the most important type for this course. Unlike a Relational Database (SQL) where every row must have the same columns (Structured), RDF allows flexibility. You can add a new property to one node without breaking the others.
these three components of a data model:
tructures: The "shape" of the data (e.g., Tables vs. Graphs).
perations: The actions: How we interact with it (e.g., SQL for tables, SPARQL for graphs).
onstraints: The rulesÔºöDatatypes, Cardinality (e.g., "Age must be an integer").
Deep Dive: Structured vs. Semi-structured (Crucial for Semantic Web):
The lecture often refers to this as "Schema-First." You must define the table columns
you can insert any data. It is rigid but efficient.

This is "Schema-Last" or flexible. You can create a node and add any property (edge) you want without asking for permission. This flexibility is what allows the Web to grow without a central authority controlling the schema.
Even though RDF has a strict syntax (Subject-Predicate-Object), it is considered semi-structured because the
(which properties belong to which classes) is not enforced by the storage engine itself in the same rigid way a SQL database enforces columns.
Decide whether a given RDF document adheres to the four Linked Data principles and explain why or why not
Use URIs as names for things.
Linked Data follows a resource-centered view of data modelling. Resources are the basic concept of web arquitecture.
Use HTTP URIs so people can look up those names Given a URI use HTTP as a mechanism to retrieve more information. They provide a mechanism for lookup and unites logical and physical address.

Provide useful information using standards (RDF, SPARQL) when someone looks up a URI RDF is the data format for Semantic Web and Linked Data. They are serializations of RDF: RDF/XML, Turtle, Notation 3, JSON LD.
Include links to other URIs Associating things from one source to things from another source creates a mesh to perform algorithms on. Links connect separate datahraphs together, re-using URIs.
These are the famous "Linked Data Principles."
This is crucial. If I name a resource
, it is a valid URI, but I cannot type it into a browser and "look it up." If I name it
When the server responds, it shouldn't just send a raw byte stream; it should send
(Structured Data) so a machine can understand it.
This creates the "Web." Without links to outside datasets (e.g., linking your city resource to DBPedia), you just have a data silo, not Linked Data.

Resource Description Framework is a graph based data model with nodes and arcs that identifies objects (URIs) and interlinks information. Describes information as a subject-predicate-object structure.
A RDF Term consists of URIs (U), blank nodes (B) and literals (L). A RDF triple has form
Blank nodes refer to resources that can only be identifies within a file and are not globally addressable. Literals refer to concrete data values as strings, integers... we use XML Schema.
The atom of data in RDF.
Can be a URI or a Blank Node.
. (A blank node or literal cannot be a predicate property).
Can be a URI, Blank Node, or Literal.
. This math notation is a common exam question format to define valid triples.
Think of them as "Existential Variables." "There exists a person who knows Bob," but we don't give that person a specific URI. They are local scope identifiers.
Turtle stands for terse RDF Triple Language. Is a textual syntax for RDF. Is a subsection of Notation3 syntax which is more expressive.
CURIEs stands for Compact URIs, a syntax for abbreviated URIs. It uses the format pref ix : reference.
To avoid repeating subject or subject and predicate we use ‚Äù;‚Äù. with only one ‚Äù.‚Äù at the end:
To nest blank nodes (from three to five)

RDF also contains different types of list:
‚Ä¢ rdf:Bag unordered set or not order relevant set
They are expressed with ‚Äù()‚Äù which is rdf:nil .
The simplest, most verbose format. No abbreviations, no prefixes. Every URI must be written out fully in
RDF only handles binary relations (Subject -> Object). If you need to say "The population was X
Use a Blank Node (as shown in your text) to group the population value and the year together, then link that Blank Node to Berlin.

2.7 Explain Linked Data principles from server/user perspective
Use HTTP server to provide access to documents
Upon receiving a request, return useful information in RDF and RDF Schema
Include links to other URIs along the information
This mirrors the 4 Principles but splits them by role.
(looking up) the URIs and following the links to discover more data (Crawling).
2.8 Read and interpret HTTP request/response pairs...
A HTTP request has a start line S consisting of a tuple ‚ü®M, u, V ‚ü© where M is the HTTP method, u is the request URI and V is the version. ... GET /about.html HTTP/1.1
A HTTP response has a start line S consisting of a tuple ‚ü®SC, V ‚ü© where SC is the status code and V is the version. ... HTTP/1.1 200 OK
The content received can be negotiated. Typically, the preference of the request data is indicated in the header of the HTTP request.
This is vital for Linked Data. The same URI (e.g.,
), the server returns an HTML page.
The thing you asked for (e.g., the city Berlin) is not a file, but I can redirect you to a file describing it.
2.9 Hash URIs vs Slash URIs & 2.10 Connection between resources
Hash URI strips off the hash of a hash URI to access the main resource.
Slash URI retrieves the document‚Äôs URI by an HTTP redirect (303). It allows for content negotiation...
Information resource: the referent of a URI belongs to a set of information if the URI does not contain a ‚Äù‚Äù an A HTTP GET on the URI results in a 200 OK.
If it contains a ‚Äù‚Äù and leads to a 303 (redirection) is considered an other resource...
How do we distinguish a real-world object (Berlin) from a document about it?
is handled by the client (browser), stripped off before sending the request to the server.
file even if you only want one small thing inside it.
Berlin is a city, not a file. You can't send a "city" over the wire.
Clean, allows unique configuration for every resource.
